title: Hands-on_Ex02
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork,
ggthemes,
tidyverse)


exam_data <- read_csv(
  "chap01/data/Exam_data.csv",
  show_col_types = FALSE
)


ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label(aes(label = ID), 
             hjust = .5, 
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: ggrepel: 317 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps








ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") 







ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()







p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")


p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")


p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

p1 + p2







(p1 / p2) | p3

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: HE03.qmd
text:
pacman::p_load(ggiraph, plotly, 
               patchwork, DT, tidyverse) 

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = ID),
    stackgroups = TRUE, 
    binwidth = 1, 
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 6,
  height_svg = 6*0.618
)




exam_data$tooltip <- c(paste0(     
  "Name = ", exam_data$ID,         
  "\n Class = ", exam_data$CLASS)) 

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(
    aes(tooltip = exam_data$tooltip), 
    stackgroups = TRUE,
    binwidth = 1,
    method = "histodot") +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(
  ggobj = p,
  width_svg = 8,
  height_svg = 8*0.618
)




tooltip_css <- "background-color:white; #<<
font-style:bold; color:black;" #<<

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = ID),                   
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(    #<<
    opts_tooltip(    #<<
      css = tooltip_css)) #<<
)     




tooltip <- function(y, ymax, accuracy = .01) {
  mean <- scales::number(y, accuracy = accuracy)
  sem <- scales::number(ymax - y, accuracy = accuracy)
  paste("Mean maths scores:", mean, "+/-", sem)
}

gg_point <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
                   aes(x = RACE),
) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS, 
                   tooltip = after_stat(  
                     tooltip(y, ymax))),  
    fun.data = "mean_se", 
    geom = GeomInteractiveCol,  
    fill = "light blue"
  ) +
  stat_summary(aes(y = MATHS),
    fun.data = mean_se,
    geom = "errorbar", width = 0.2, size = 0.2
  )

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

girafe(ggobj = gg_point,
       width_svg = 8,
       height_svg = 8*0.618)




p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(           
    aes(data_id = CLASS),             
    stackgroups = TRUE,               
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618                      
)                                        




p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)                                        




p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(tooltip = CLASS, 
        data_id = CLASS),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618,
  options = list(                        
    opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),  
    opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;") 
  )                                        
)                                        




exam_data$onclick <- sprintf("window.open(\"%s%s\")",
"https://www.moe.gov.sg/schoolfinder?journey=Primary%20school",
as.character(exam_data$ID))

p <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(onclick = onclick),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +               
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)
girafe(                                  
  ggobj = p,                             
  width_svg = 6,                         
  height_svg = 6*0.618)                                        




p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_dotplot_interactive(              
    aes(data_id = ID),              
    stackgroups = TRUE,                  
    binwidth = 1,                        
    method = "histodot") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,               
                     breaks = NULL)

girafe(code = print(p1 + p2), 
       width_svg = 6,
       height_svg = 3,
       options = list(
         opts_hover(css = "fill: #202020;"),
         opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;")
         )
       )

title: HE04
text:
pacman::p_load(ggdist, ggridges, ggthemes,
               colorspace, tidyverse)

exam <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

ggplot(exam, 
       aes(x = ENGLISH, 
           y = CLASS)) +
  geom_density_ridges(
    scale = 3,
    rel_min_height = 0.01,
    bandwidth = 3.4,
    fill = lighten("#7097BB", .3),
    color = "white"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "English grades",
    expand = c(0, 0)
    ) +
  scale_y_discrete(name = NULL, expand = expansion(add = c(0.2, 2.6))) +
  theme_ridges()







ggplot(exam, 
       aes(x = ENGLISH, 
           y = CLASS,
           fill = stat(x))) +
  geom_density_ridges_gradient(
    scale = 3,
    rel_min_height = 0.01) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Temp. [F]",
                       option = "C") +
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "English grades",
    expand = c(0, 0)
  ) +
  scale_y_discrete(name = NULL, expand = expansion(add = c(0.2, 2.6))) +
  theme_ridges()

Warning: `stat(x)` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `after_stat(x)` instead.


Picking joint bandwidth of 3.18








ggplot(exam,
       aes(x = ENGLISH, 
           y = CLASS, 
           fill = 0.5 - abs(0.5-stat(ecdf)))) +
  stat_density_ridges(geom = "density_ridges_gradient", 
                      calc_ecdf = TRUE) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Tail probability",
                       direction = -1) +
  theme_ridges()

Picking joint bandwidth of 3.18








ggplot(exam,
       aes(x = ENGLISH,

df <- covid19 %>%
  mutate(rate = Death / Positive) %>%
  mutate(rate.se = sqrt((rate*(1-rate)) / (Positive))) %>%
  filter(rate > 0)

fit.mean <- weighted.mean(df$rate, 1/df$rate.se^2)

number.seq <- seq(1, max(df$Positive), 1)
number.ll95 <- fit.mean - 1.96 * sqrt((fit.mean*(1-fit.mean)) / (number.seq)) 
number.ul95 <- fit.mean + 1.96 * sqrt((fit.mean*(1-fit.mean)) / (number.seq)) 
number.ll999 <- fit.mean - 3.29 * sqrt((fit.mean*(1-fit.mean)) / (number.seq)) 
number.ul999 <- fit.mean + 3.29 * sqrt((fit.mean*(1-fit.mean)) / (number.seq)) 
dfCI <- data.frame(number.ll95, number.ul95, number.ll999, 
                   number.ul999, number.seq, fit.mean)

p <- ggplot(df, aes(x = Positive, y = rate)) +
  geom_point(aes(label=`Sub-district`), 
             alpha=0.4) +
  geom_line(data = dfCI, 
            aes(x = number.seq, 
                y = number.ll95), 
            size = 0.4, 
            colour = "grey40", 
            linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_line(data = dfCI, 
            aes(x = number.seq, 
                y = number.ul95), 
            size = 0.4, 
            colour = "grey40",

  geom_line(data = dfCI, 
            aes(x = number.seq, 
                y = number.ll999),

  geom_line(data = dfCI,

                y = number.ul999),

  geom_hline(data = dfCI,

# reusable function for creating annotation object
label <- function(txt) {
  list(
    text = txt, 
    x = 0.1, y = 1,
    ax = 0, ay = 0,
    xref = "paper", yref = "paper", 
    align = "center",
    font = list(family = "serif", size = 15, color = "white"),
    bgcolor = "#b3b3b3", bordercolor = "black", borderwidth = 2
  )
}

# reusable function for axis formatting
axis <- function(txt) {
  list(
    title = txt, tickformat = ".0%", tickfont = list(size = 10)
  )
}

ternaryAxes <- list(
  aaxis = axis("Young"), 
  baxis = axis("Active"), 
  caxis = axis("Old")
)

# Initiating a plotly visualization 
plot_ly(
  agpop_mutated, 
  a = ~YOUNG, 
  b = ~ACTIVE, 
  c = ~OLD, 
  color = I("black"), 
  type = "scatterternary"
) %>%
  layout(
    annotations = label("Ternary Markers"), 
    ternary = ternaryAxes
  )

panel.cor <- function(x, y, digits=2, prefix="", cex.cor, ...) {
usr <- par("usr")
on.exit(par(usr))
par(usr = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
r <- abs(cor(x, y, use="complete.obs"))
txt <- format(c(r, 0.123456789), digits=digits)[1]
txt <- paste(prefix, txt, sep="")
if(missing(cex.cor)) cex.cor <- 0.8/strwidth(txt)
text(0.5, 0.5, txt, cex = cex.cor * (1 + r) / 2)
}

title: TakeHomeExercise1
text:
Import data
The dataset used in the exercise is survey raw data retrieved from the https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S235234092100576X. We import this dataset as survey_raw_data.

survey_raw_data <- read_csv("data/Upload for elsiver.csv",show_col_types = FALSE)
parsing_issue <- problems(survey_raw_data)

print(parsing_issue)

# A tibble: 0 × 5
# ℹ 5 variables: row <int>, col <int>, expected <chr>, actual <chr>, file <chr>

title: TakeHomeExercise1
text:
Data pre-processing
We first take a look at the data, and handle data when necessary.

Summary of data
Using the glimpse function, we saw the data has correct 725 rows and 30 columns, mainly in double type, and have many NA values. We first need to select the variables for our study, then for the selected variables, convert the correct type and handle NA values. We don’t need to check duplicates for records, as the records with same survey answer won’t be accounted as duplicated records in our case.

glimpse(survey_raw_data)

Rename selected variables
将变量名重命名为更具可读性的标签，保证理解清晰

library(dplyr)

survey_raw_data <- survey_raw_data %>%
  rename(
    province = CPRO,
    gender = CGEN,
    race = CRAC,
    career = CJOB,
    income_quintile = CQUI,
    total_income = TEIN,
    agri_income = TAIN,
    service_industrial_income = TSII,
    others_income = TOIN,
    education = FEDU,
    vocational_training = FVTP,
    credit_accessibility = FCRA,
    tech_application = FTAP,
    cottage_house = LHO1,
    roofed_house = LHO2,
    solid_house = LHO3,
    building = LHO4,
    real_loan = LCRE,
    saving = LSAV,
    working_days = LWDA
  )



Convert data types
根据数据说明，将名义型数据转换为factor，序数型数据转换为ordered factor, scale数据保持double类型

# 转换为因子（Nominal 变量）
nominal_vars <- c("province", "career", "income_quintile", "education", "PPO1", "PPO2", "PPO3", "PPO4", "PPO5", 
                  "ARO1", "ARO2", "ARO3", "ARO4", "ARO5")
survey_raw_data[nominal_vars] <- lapply(survey_raw_data[nominal_vars], as.factor)

# 转换为有序因子（Ordinal 变量）
survey_raw_data$gender <- factor(survey_raw_data$gender, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("Male", "Female"))
survey_raw_data$race <- factor(survey_raw_data$race, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("King", "Minorities"))
survey_raw_data$vocational_training <- ordered(survey_raw_data$vocational_training, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("No", "Yes"))
survey_raw_data$credit_accessibility <- ordered(survey_raw_data$credit_accessibility, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("No", "Yes"))
survey_raw_data$tech_application <- ordered(survey_raw_data$tech_application, levels = c(1, 2), labels = c("Low", "Adequate"))



Reselect the variables for research scope

selected_vars <- c("province", "gender", "race", "career", "income_quintile", 
                   "total_income", "agri_income", "service_industrial_income", "others_income", "education", 
                   "vocational_training", "credit_accessibility")
analysis_data <- survey_raw_data %>%
  select(all_of(selected_vars))



Preview pre-processed dataframe
After summarizing the selected variables, we observed that career has 49 NA values and education has 23 NA values.

To clean the data more effectively for each research question without losing too many samples, two separate cleaned datasets will be created for further analysis.
data_topic1 will be used for Research Question 1, focusing on income, education, vocational training, and credit accessibility. data_topic2 will be used for Research Question 2, focusing on gender, race, career choices, and income.

# 数据集 1: 用于课题一 (收入分布，教育、职业培训天数和信贷可得性对收入的影响)
data_topic1 <- analysis_data %>%
  select(province, gender, race, income_quintile, total_income, agri_income, 
         service_industrial_income, others_income, education, vocational_training, credit_accessibility) %>%
  filter(complete.cases(.)) # 删除带有NA值的行

# 数据集 2: 用于课题二 (性别和种族对职业选择和收入的影响)
data_topic2 <- analysis_data %>%
  select(province, gender, race, career, total_income) %>%
  filter(complete.cases(.)) # 删除带有NA值的行

# 打印删除后每个数据集的行数和缺失值情况
